text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with another installment of the
cooking with grass-fed beef this time we
have some beautiful sirloin tips from
steve normanton that we're going to make
some thai style beef skewers with so I
guess we could call this beef satay
although I'm not sure how authentic this
is but anyway let's get started we're
going to take our boneless sirloin tip
and it's already in a nice shape to cut
thin slices basically this recipe is
going to work with any thinly sliced
beef a lot of people will splurge and
use a beef tenderloin for this which is
ultra tender and really nice I have to
admit but I like something a little
firmer a little chewier with a lot of
flavor like the sirloin tip you can even
use a really tough cut of meat like a
rump roast something like that and as
long as you slice it really thin against
the grain some people even will pound it
it'll work
alright for the marinade and that's
really what this recipe is for the
marinade we're going to take some garlic
some brown sugar some fish sauce some
soy sauce some cumin some tumeric and
some ground coriander and then one of
the stars of the show here lemongrass I
use the pure lemongrass puree they sell
in the tubes I think very convenient if
you want to use fresh lemongrass and
know how to work with that go forward of
course some freshly grated ginger and
some fresh lime juice all right we're
going to mix that up that is the
marinade so simple and so incredibly
delicious so I'm gonna toss my beef in
there my sirloin tip and I'm going to
let it marinade for four to six hours
that's ideal to me some people like to
go longer they go overnight up to you
I'm going to make sure I soak my skewers
for at least one hour and water and then
we're going to secure now here is the
deal with scaring as far as I'm
concerned because I'm using this
grass-fed sirloin tip I want the outside
to get a nice caramelization before the
inside cooks so I'm going to weave on
like three or four pieces so I have a
lot of beef on a skier in restaurants
sometimes you order the beef satay they
will spread it out like this like one or
two pieces per stick but it cooks a lot
quicker so the outside doesn't really
caramelize as much so I have about three
of those slices per skier all right
we're going to go out to a very hot
grill
and you know the rest IOL degrades
before I put the meat down and because
there's brown sugar it's going to stick
but that's only initially if you give it
a couple minutes you'll see it'll
caramelize and release from the grill
now again this is why I like to weave
very tightly three pieces of meat or
four pieces of meat so that I can get a
nice sear on there a nice char a nice
caramelization and the inside is still
going to stay kind of pink if this was
all stretched out thin I'd have to turn
those in like a minute and they'd be
cooked and they'd be fast but they
wouldn't get that nice caramelized char
on there to me that's what really makes
the dish alright so I'm going to cook
the rest of my satay and I'm going to
serve this with a nice cucumber salad
just cucumber rice vinegar a little
onion little Fresno chili and also a
nice peanut sauce lots of fresh cilantro
maybe a little fresh lime you know you
do it up how you want let me test this
out oh my that is so delicious gotta try
this and you know grilling seasons
coming up and your friends they're nice
if they were bored with your grill
recipes they wouldn't tell you so you
know what don't take any chances
mix this one in there shake things up a
little bit all the ingredients are on
the site so go check it out and as
always enjoy
